title: Friday, 24th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:01am

Hey! Hello. Hi. Good morning. Welcome.

BE11:02am

Hey-oh! Little joke to start the day, there.

BE11:02am

Mercy, we have some fun don't we? Stocks fun.

11:02 am
BE11:02am

Have a tweet.

BE11:02am

BE11:03am

Which I believe sums up the true meaning of Black Friday.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Because who among us doesn't need copy and link? Let's get on.

undefined
BE11:04am

So, straight into yesterday's news I guess.

11:04 am
William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 280.60, down 3.2 (-1.13%), High: 287.00, Low: 279.30, Volume: 1.15m
BE11:04am

It might be useful to provide a quick timeline of how this one developed.

BE11:04am

As in, 4pm UK time The Australian publishes:

11:04 am
BE11:05am

CrownBet, William Hill talk merger. CrownBet and its rival William Hill are believed to have held in-depth talks on a potential deal in the first round of consolidation expected to emerge in the corporate bookmaking industry in the next few months.

DataRoom understands that Credit Suisse is involved in the negotiations on a transaction that could happen shortly that would bring the two corporate bookmakers together.

BE11:05am

It's behind a paywall, of course, and not many people in London have an Australian sub.

BE11:05am

The first most people heard of it was when Bloomberg flashed this, at 4.06pm ....

11:05 am
BE11:05am

WILLIAM HILL, CROWNBET ARE SAID TO HOLD MERGER TALK: AUSTRALIAN

BE11:06am

..... some people went, "eh? How would Crownbet -- a startup in a pissant market that only does sub $200m revenue a year -- merge with William Hill?"

BE11:06am

But those weren't the people in charge of the buttons yesterday afternoon, clearly, because William Hill shares shot up 9% or so.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Then, at 4.29pm!

BE11:06am

(Bloomberg) -- William Hill Chief Executive Officer Philip Bowcock met with CrownBet in Australia to discuss industry matters, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. The companies are not in talks on a merger, the person said.

BE11:06am

Then, at 11.29pm!

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Crown Resorts Limited (ASX: CWN) ("Crown") notes media speculation today in relation to consolidation in the online wagering industry, including in relation to CrownBet, which is 62% owned by Crown. Crown evaluates opportunities regarding its investments from time to time.

Crown confirms that it is in discussions concerning its interest in CrownBet. There is no certainty as to whether any transaction will eventuate.

BE11:07am

Then, at 7.30am!

BE11:07am

Following media speculation, William Hill confirms that it is in very preliminary discussions with CrownBet, the 62% owned online wagering business of Crown Resorts, regarding a possible combination of William Hill Australia, a wholly owned subsidiary of William Hill, and CrownBet.

There is no certainty that these preliminary discussions will lead to any transaction.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Thumbs up

BE11:07am

Can you spot the odd one out here?

BE11:07am

I'll give you a clue, it's the one that cites "a person with knowledge of the matter"

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Now, weirdly, we put in the calls to people with knowledge of the matter yesterday and could only get a straight bat.

BE11:08am

No comment, no guidance, no deep off the record guidance, no response to the "if I report this will I end up looking stupid?" question ... nothing.

BE11:08am

But perhaps we didn't get to speak to the same person with knowledge of the matter as Bloomberg did.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

But ........... Well ...............

BE11:09am

What we can say here is that it must be a person speaking must've been trusted enough to be allowed to communicate anonymously to the market.

BE11:09am

This isn't normal. Stories don't hang one anonymous single source, though. For obvious reasons.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The only exception is for when newswires are in a rush to shitbag stories that have appeared on other media. That's when they cite one person with knowledge of the matter.

BE11:10am

However ........ if the people with knowledge of the matter abuse their special status to tell porkies, what then?

BE11:10am

Wither the newswires? And wither the burgeoning "people with knowledge of the matter" industry? Wither?

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Wither, I ask?

BE11:10am

Anyway.

BE11:10am

Back to the detail. Oz consolidation would be a small but not insignificant positive for William Hill, which needs to do something to fix the Sportingbet business for which it hugely overpaid.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Oz currently looks like this:

BE11:11am

BE11:11am

That's via Goldman, which goes on:

11:11 am
BE11:11am

CrownBet is an Australian online gambling company (62% owned by Crown Resorts), with FY16 revenue of AUD157 mn but negative EBITDA at -9% margin. William Hill’s Australia business generated AUD209 mn of revenues and AUD35.5 mn of EBITDA, representing c.7% of group revenue and c.5.9% of EBIT.

BE11:11am

[T]he Australian market remains highly fragmented and we expect consolidation in Australia to accelerate as a new
point-of-consumption (POC) tax is likely to be implemented across the country in FY19. While the implications for William Hill will depend on the terms of the transaction if one were to happen, we believe consolidation in Australia would be positive and scale could help William Hill to offset margin pressures from the new POC tax.

BE11:11am

And Stifel

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Australia has been a major underperformer for WMH in recent years; last year the business generated EBIT of £15m on revenues of £114m, compared to an acquisition cost of almost £500m in 2013. Moreover, the business faces significant tax and regulatory pressure in the form of a ban on credit business (30% of its revenue) from February 2018 and the likely implementation of a 15% point of consumption tax on a state by state basis.

CrownBet is also facing pressures in the market. Against this background, it seems logical for the two companies to explore whether a transaction can be agreed. We view this as an encouraging and logical development but note that the talks are “very preliminary” and that corporate transactions in the sector are often aborted. In the context of William Hill, a successful transaction could create modest upside in the context of the group as a whole and deal with a troubled business.

BE11:12am

And Canaccord:

BE11:12am

WMH's foray into Australia has been fairly disastrous, with the acquisitions of Sportingbet/Tom Waterhouse bulking up the business, but a challenging integration, and tightening regulation resulting in a significant decline in its profits, which have more than halved since 2014. Only 6% of group profits, and with the impending ban on credit betting and increased taxation, it is set to fall further. Combination makes sense, given scale advantages, but unlikely to move the dial on William Hill. But timely reminder that there is going to be a lot more consolidation activity in this space. Ladbrokes Coral (LCL-LSE : 136p | Buy, TP 165p) remains our preferred play among the bookies.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@VV75: dude, that's a Reuters story. It's really not right that Bloomberg's the Oscar Wilde of news citations. It aggregates as well as reports.)

BE11:14am

So ......... what we can say here is that Crownbet is for sale.

BE11:15am

Paddy Power, with 22% of the market, will take a look (as per the story just up on Reuters.)

11:15 am
Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 8,710, up 175 (+2.05%), High: 8,710, Low: 8,475, Volume: 170.02k
BE11:16am

Ladbrokes, with 8%, will probably take a look assuming it's not also trying to shove GVC out of its office at the time.

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 134.40, down 1.2 (-0.88%), High: 136.40, Low: 133.30, Volume: 1.21m
11:17 am
BE11:17am

And whatever happens, really, a market with about a dozen operators will be reduced to a market with .... a dozen operators. Super.

undefined
BE11:18am

(@VV75: no worries, just being grumpy.)

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Here's the link for your fill of German politics: https://www.ft.com...-9dbb-291a884dd8c6

BE11:19am

Germany’s Social Democrats are ready to talk to their conservative rivals about the formation of a government led by Angela Merkel in a potentially decisive move to break the political deadlock in Berlin.

The decision, announced early on Friday after an eight-hour meeting of SPD leaders in Berlin, marks a U-turn for the centre-left party, which had backed new elections as recently as Monday.

“The SPD is firmly convinced that talks have to take place. The SPD is not closed to talks,” Hubertus Heil, the general secretary, said early on Friday.

BE11:21am

I'm totally lost on what now constitutes a grand coalition and what's unacceptable for whom. For a full discussion, head into the comment box, which has become an unofficial gathering point for German constitutional experts.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Over here, we'll just stick to markets stuff.

undefined
BE11:23am

Sorry, brief pause there for an offline conversation.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

What else?

BE11:24am

It'd be too much to say that the knife catchers have arrived in Centrica, but the short closers are here.

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 135.30, down 2.7 (-1.96%), High: 138.30, Low: 134.90, Volume: 14.79m
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Such as Investec.

BE11:25am

Centrica shows the hallmarks of a business under tremendous pressure – from competitors, customers, and policy makers. Business energy supply is now added to the medley of woes. Questions will invariably be raised regarding management’s grasp on performance and risks. We update FY17E forecasts in line with guidance, assume lower normalised B2B margins, and now include the impact of the expected UK domestic supply price cap on earnings from FY19E. However, after a c. 40% YTD share price fall, our revised TP of 140p means we upgrade to HOLD.

BE11:26am

Heading into the detail, they're going for a 30% cut to the divi in 2018.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Goldman, also, turning less negative to highlight that it was previously negative.

BE11:27am

Following the weak share price performance year to date (-37%
total return, -50% total return versus SX6P) we upgrade Centrica to Neutral (from Sell). On our new estimates, Centrica trades on 10.9x 2020E P/E, which implies an 8% discount vs. peers on 12x. We continue to see downside risks to UK supply as highlighted in our September 7, 2016 report, UK Utilities: Structural headwinds to gas supply, Sell Centrica. In particular, we expect profits in gas supply to fall as a result of low-cost competition. However we believe this is now priced into the shares with the stock trading 7% below our
new 12-month price target of 149p (was 163p) and hence upgrade
the shares

BE11:28am

Since being added to the Sell List on September 7, 2016, the shares
are down 41% vs. FTSE World Europe up 17%.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

They're on for a 12p divi in 2018, as in held.

BE11:29am

And again in 2019, then the cut comes in 2020 to 9.5p.

BE11:02am

It's Black Friday. And here at Markets Live we're 50% off ..... presenters!

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Following the weak share price performance year to date (-37% total return, -50% total return versus SX6P) we upgrade Centrica to Neutral (from Sell) and cut our 12-month price target from 163p to 149p. Our price target is based 40% on a P/E valuation of 152p (from 162p, mainly to reflect lower earnings) , 40% on a SOTP valuation of 144p (from 158p to reflect a weaker outlook for North America and UK business) and 20% on a DDM valuation of 151p (from 177p, to reflect the cut in dividend). Our P/E valuation applies a FY20E P/E of 12x, in line with the sector average (excluding CNA) to reflect the impact of the weaker outlook within UK supply and the impact of the Cheniere gas contract. We expect this impact to come through FY19 onwards

undefined
BE11:30am

Otherwise ........

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Quiet in the US today, for obvious reasons. Though folk still watching Juniper Networks. Not totally sure why.

BE11:31am

Its management was on tour last week post Q3 numbers.

BE11:32am

Talking up the migration from MX routers to PTX, which is better at sharing the load between your datacentres apparently.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Amazon already making the upgrade, others to follow.

BE11:32am

Sales/margins currently depressed as customers pause purchases for an architecture rejig. That's the theory.

BE11:32am

Anyway, some folk suggesting Juniper might make sense as a target for one of the big semi makers. Which seems a bit leftfield, buy you never know I guess.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Folk also keen to gossip about Shire right now.

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,710, down 25.5 (-0.68%), High: 3,740, Low: 3,694, Volume: 248.73k
BE11:33am

On which we can make the usual points ......

11:33 am
BE11:34am

As in, Baxalta has been a disaster but has been pretty much written off in the valuation, if not the carrying value yet.

BE11:35am

We've got Roche's Haven-4 study still to come, mid 2018.

BE11:35am

Quick line from HSBC there ......

11:35 am
BE11:35am

The advantage with Hemlibra is the combination of a sub-cutaneous injection (versus intravenous for Factor VIII therapies) and once weekly dosing (versus up to several times a week for Factor VIII). In our view, that makes Hemlibra a highly competitive and disruptive drug. However, Haven-4 data, with once monthly dosing, are due by c. mid-2018. If that study is successful, in our view, there is further downside risk to forecasts for Shire’s haemophilia franchise revenues.

BE11:36am

[W]e believe Shire may already have backed away from its 2020 guidance of USD20bn in revenues and the forecast may be abandoned. However, now with the approval of Hemlibra, further approvals likely and with the prospect of a once monthly formulation that could negatively impact the value of Shire’s haemophilia franchise even further, it is reasonable to wonder whether Shire should re-assess the carrying value of the Baxalta acquisition and whether an impairment might be appropriate.

BE11:37am

On the flipside, Shire's about 40% cheaper in dollar terms then when Abbvie was trying to buy it.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

And you've got an update on the possible spinoff or sale of neurology expected pretty soon.

BE11:39am

As I say, not sure why punters are taking an interest right now. But it's really not hard to build a case around Shire looking a bit vulnerable.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:40am

(@Pharma: be fair, I haven't sabotaged a deal for months.)

BE11:42am

WYG mentioned.

WYG PLC (WYG:LSE): Last: 67.00, no change, Volume: 257.33k
11:43 am
BE11:43am

That, clearly, isn't a live price. Live is down 30% or so.

BE11:43am

Profit warning.

BE11:44am

Pre results at the start of December, which suggests a rather short visibility between intended numbers and actual numbers.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

WH Ireland can summarise:

BE11:44am

We see these reflecting negative trends in some of the UK engineering / infrastructure business streams, where the company faces competitive pressures and evidence suggests that clients can be slow to close in the current environment. For the international businesses, and bearing in mind previous forecast adjustments, we are leaving these numbers unchanged; but overall, having previously forecast a similar H2-18E to last year’s weak H2, we are now revising forecasts materially downwards. We continue to expect change within the business, led by CEO Douglas McCormick and some relatively new senior appointments

BE11:44am

As can Finncap.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

International Development business is performing in line with previously revised expectations, but Consultancy Services has continued to experience lower trading volumes than anticipated. This is due to the loss or delay of certain new contracts that the group had expected to win and significantly lower volumes of work under certain major framework contracts. Operating profit is now expected to be in the range of £3.5m to £4.0m (our current expectation £7.1m). Net debt is expected to be in £6-£7m (our current expectation £5m). While clearly disappointing, the medium to long-term opportunity remains undiminished, supported by UK investment in infrastructure. We will downgrade our forecasts in line with the announcement and await further detail from management on how a return to growth will be achieved.

BE11:45am

As can Singer, which is shop.

BE11:45am

Since the trading update in August, WYG’s Consultancy Services business has continued to face challenges. As a result, the Board has taken a more cautious view of the full year outlook and we revise our forecasts accordingly, reducing PBT by 57% in FY18/43% in FY19. Today’s statement is brief (more detailed commentary will follow in the interims on 5th December) but it is clear that the issue principally relates to lower than expected activity levels in the UK. Whilst it is disappointing to downgrade forecasts again, the order book is strong and the new management team is taking steps to address recent underperformance and return WYG to growth.

11:45 am
undefined
BE11:47am

(@Mouselet: yep, sorry, proprietary.)

BE11:48am

(@Mouslet: sorry.)

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Speaking of engineering, Renishaw from UBS is about the only thing among the sellside that looks vaguely interesting.

BE11:49am

Part of a sector note.

BE11:49am

Upshot is that Renishaw's expensive. But the working's good.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

The theme is that, sector wide, sales growth isn't transferring to earnings.

BE11:50am

Eight out of 13 UK engineers beat on organic top line growth in Q3 with average organic growth in the period at 7%. However, only three raised expectations. Continuing the theme of H1, cost increases were highlighted – a mix of raw materials, staff costs, and business investments. A median average upgrade of only 1% for our first year forecasts seems scant reward for continued strong top lines growth. With growth rates potentially rolling over this increases risk that future upgrades may remain relatively limited. The median share price in the sector was +2% over the reporting season, although there was significant variation with the companies raising expectations generally rewarded.

BE11:51am

So, stock pick.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Investors need to be selective in the UK engineering sector. Tailwinds from currency and commodities are fading and leading indicators may be peaking. The sector is up c80% since the start of 2016 and this has taken us to peak absolute valuations. Our analysis suggesting c16-34% upgrades could be priced means there are risks that despite the robust momentum the sector will struggle to perform. We have four Buy ratings in the UK engineers focused on lower rated names with cyclical upside potential (Bodycote and Vesuvius) or self-help (Rotork, Melrose). We have Sell ratings on companies where we do not see potential volume uplifts providing the level of upgrades the rating needs: Halma, IMI and Spectris. We also downgrade Renishaw to Sell with this report with the valuation now at a c70% sector premium.

Renishaw PLC (RSW:LSE): Last: 5,435, down 120 (-2.16%), High: 5,545, Low: 5,410, Volume: 33.95k
IMI PLC (IMI:LSE): Last: 1,260, up 6 (+0.48%), High: 1,260, Low: 1,241, Volume: 102.25k
11:52 am
Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 202.80, up 1.2 (+0.60%), High: 202.80, Low: 200.10, Volume: 817.83k
Bodycote PLC (BOY:LSE): Last: 888.50, down 6 (-0.67%), High: 894.50, Low: 881.00, Volume: 64.10k
undefined
11:56 am
BE11:56am

That long pause was for me to try and find anything whatsoever to fill the last ten minutes with. This job ain't easy on a Friday, after a dull week, on Thanksgiving.

BE11:57am

On Unilever spreads sale, noising coming from the debt folk about funding being secured.

BE11:58am

But we've been down that road many times before. Last guidance from was for Q1 completion, I think.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Oh, Informa! Sure, Informa.

Informa PLC (INF:LSE): Last: 766.50, up 15 (+2.00%), High: 766.50, Low: 752.50, Volume: 555.14k
BE11:59am

That's Liberum pushing.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

We downgrade UBM to a Hold from a Buy and, conversely, upgrade Informa from a Hold to a Buy. In the past, our position was UBM was the best way to play Events as a pure play business, especially as we had doubts over Informa’s asset quality and its ability to execute a turnaround. Now, while Informa is very much on track driven by an impressive performance in its events, there are more questions over why UBM’s performance has not been better. In our view, these doubts have reached a point to recommend INF as the preferred way to play events from a mid to large cap perspective.

UBM PLC (UBM:LSE): Last: 745.50, down 2.5 (-0.33%), High: 748.00, Low: 726.00, Volume: 345.09k
undefined
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

And yeah, okay, FTSE rejig.

BE12:00pm

Fixed on Tuesday closing prices.

BE12:01pm

Ceteris paribus we're four in/out

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Just Eat is nearly certain, as is DS Smith. Out go Merlin and Mediclinic and Convatec and Babcock.

BE12:02pm

Halma and John Wood make up the diffrence.

BE12:03pm

Here's SocGen's estimate on passive demand and etc.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

BE12:04pm

FTSE 250 and smalls go like this.

BE12:05pm

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Weird times when Restaurant Group's a smallcap and Just Eat's in the 100.

BE12:06pm

There's a thinkpiece in that about intermediaries and asset-light versus actually doing stuff and owning stuff. But I'll not be the person to write it.

BE12:07pm

Because we're through midday. \o/

12:06 pm
undefined
BE12:07pm

Thanks for your time, your patience and your many insightful observations ROTR.

BE12:07pm

Back next week.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:30am

Valuation work:
